text: watch the bouncing droplet what makes it
go the researchers at a swiss university
who did this experiment are interested
in practical matters like de-icing
airplane wings but in order to
understand everything about that process
they study the basic behavior of water
in this experiment they wanted to figure
out the effects of low pressure when
water was on a synthetic nonstick
surface at a microscopic level the
droplets rest on little bumps on the
surface like a body on a bed of nails
when they lowered the pressure in a
closed chamber that speeded up
evaporation some water vapour dissipated
but vapor trapped under the droplets
couldn't easily escape the force of that
vapor trying to escape is what launches
the droplet into the air when the drops
that falls back down it compresses the
vapor again the result is like the
action of a spring or a person jumping
on a trampoline the droplet bounces even
higher
in cold temperatures and low pressure
rapid freezing and evaporation can also
cause levitation these discoveries
aren't of practical use yet but who
knows where they'll lead
